response.answer_text: These are all pretty good answers. In order to find who sampled what, there is the website : Discover Music via Samples, Cover Songs and Remixes | WhoSampled Unfortunately, I don’t know one resource as comprehensive then this that would do a similar job for soundtracks. If I understand well what you wanna do, you want to provide the title of a song and see a list of all film soundtracks it has been used in. Also, http://www.discogs.com AllMusic | Record Reviews, Streaming Songs, Genres & Bands can be good for that because they list all different pressings of a song very exhaustively, so if it has appeared on a soundtrack (because not all movies have their soundtrack commercialized and when they do not all the songs necessarily appear on it) you should see it in the list. Then, Ratings and Reviews for New Movies and TV Shows - IMDb have a soundtrack repertory which is somewhat of a work in progress, so it is possible to find it there. There are also a couple of specialized minor sites. They are not the most nicely organized, but they both have a pretty big database. Songs from movies [SoundtrackCollector - The Movie Soundtrack Database](The Movie Soundtrack Database) On any sites you want to look, if the search engine provided by the site doesn’t suit your needs, it’s a good idea to use some of Google's advanced search functionalities. Like if you want to know what movie the song I Don’t Want to Miss a Thing. was in, you can type a query like this in google I Don’t Want to Miss a Thing site:soundtrackcollector.com which will give only hits from that particular website. If you want narrow your search, even more, put the title of the song in quotes “I Don’t Want to Miss a Thing” site:soundtrackcollector.com Depending on the popularity of the song you’re looking for, if it has been a single and a minimum successful, the Wikipedia page for that song will most likely cite where it has been used. If it hasn’t been a single but has appeared on a singer or band album, then there’s a big chance, the page for the album will mention it. If you still don’t find you can take a look at The Open Music Encyclopedia They have an extensive list of resources dedicated to music and they also have apps and tools you can use to find information.

Okay, so say you don’t know the name of that particular song, try to remember little snippets of the lyrics that are unlikely to be found in other songs. For example, there was once I simply couldn’t for the life of me remember where I’d heard the line ‘stupid Cupid, stop picking on me’ (yeah, I didn’t know that song back then) so I googled ‘stupid Cupid, stop picking on me lyrics’ and found the song’s name and artiste in the search results. Now to find what movie I’d heard it in that’s been bugging me. I just Wikipedia’d the song. This method works for famous songs, and it might for the not-so-popular tracks. In Wikipedia, it will be mentioned where the song has been featured in. (films, tv series, etc.) OR You can Wikipedia the movie instead and keep scrolling until you reach the soundtrack section. If the song is in the movie’s soundtrack, it’ll be in the track list, but if it’s just featured in the movie, then there might be a sentence at the end if the ‘Soundtrack’ section that says: This song has also been featured in the film…. whatever. Hope this helped! :)

IMDb (Internet Movie Database) lists almost every film ever made. If you type in the composer/singer’s name and then do a page search (ctrl F) for the name of the song, the films/series/games/shorts/etc where the song has appeared will be highlighted. If you’re trying to find a song that played in a film whose tune you can remember but whose title you can’t, go to www.what-song.com and type in the film’s title. You’ll be able to hear a segment of most of the songs in the film, complete with their title and singer/composer.

Look up the song on YouTube, look through the comments, and take note of all the things that people say “brought them there.” Really, that’s the way I do it. It works well, if it’s a bit time-consuming, filtering through all the people who were “born in the wrong generation,” are “unusually dark and quirky,” and are “still listening in 2019.” The Wikipedia page for a song may be able to help you with this as well, if it’s a famous-enough song, and various lyric/song-meaning sites will likely mention movies a song has been in. There may also be YouTube compilations of movie scenes with a particular song.

Wikipedia is an invaluable resource for finding music in movies! :-) It lists any movies, TV shows, etc., where a certain song has been used! :-) Here is an example of the page for “Baby Got Back” - Sir Mix-a-Lot Baby Got Back - Wikipedia IMDB is another helpful resource! :-) If you search for a movie, you can scroll down to see what’s on the soundtrack! :-) IMDb: Ratings, Reviews, and Where to Watch the Best Movies & TV Shows Also, if you are watching a movie and you want to know the name/artist of a song that’s playing, the SoundHound App is great, too! :-) Technology for a voice-enabled world | SoundHound Inc.

Lots of good answers! IMDB click the down arrow next to the search box on the home page and click advanced search. On the Advanced search page in the box that says Movies, TV and Video Games, there is a box that says plot, click the down arrow and select soundtracks. In the box to the right of this enter the name of the song! Enjoy! Thanks IMDB!

Go to IMDb. You can look up the soundtracks on there. Say I’m looking for a certain song. I go to the IMDb page for the band or artist that did it. We’ll just do Lou Reed for this example. Here you’ll see all of the movies and TV shows featuring his songs.  Then just look through it, and I’m sure you’ll find the song you’re looking for.

If the versions have appeared on official soundtracks, you can do a song search on AllMusic : Music Search, Recommendations, Videos and Reviews - their listings are pretty comprehensive, though sometimes incomplete.

Try this by example, since it's the best response I’ve found; ask Google: what movies has the song, Dead Man's Party, in it's credits? FYI, it's a classic movie, with an incredible comedian, in a starring role! Movie title known/song title not known….? Ask the opposite. If you don't know the name of the song/artist but are able to access the music, download 'Shazam' to your phone - brilliant for identifying tracks.
